head.title: Letting Primary Voters Have a Say

hedline.hl1: Letting Primary Voters Have a Say

abstract.p: Michael J Gaynor letter points out that fairer, slower and more democratic is not necessarily better than intense, competitive and quick when it comes to primary elections (S)

block.p: You describe this year's primaries as ''intense, competitive and, as a practical matter, over very quickly'' and endorse the Brock commission's plan for ''a fairer, slower, more democratic primary season'' (editorial, May 4).

Fairer, slower and more democratic is not necessarily better than intense, competitive and over very quickly. What may seem in theory to be fairer, slower and more democratic may in reality be only slower.

You describe this year's primaries as ''intense, competitive and, as a practical matter, over very quickly'' and endorse the Brock commission's plan for ''a fairer, slower, more democratic primary season'' (editorial, May 4).

Fairer, slower and more democratic is not necessarily better than intense, competitive and over very quickly. What may seem in theory to be fairer, slower and more democratic may in reality be only slower.

Presidents need to deal with intense, competitive, quickly moving situations. The present system provided a good test. And the latest group of candidates had more than enough time to develop their campaigns.
The news media may prefer, and profit from, a much longer primary season, but there will be other stories to cover when presidential nominations are secured early.
MICHAEL J. GAYNOR Greenlawn, N.Y., May 4, 2000
